title: #131 – Beth Lewis: The Art of Stability: Learning about pain, mitigating injury, and moving better through life
content: Check out more content with movement specialist, Beth Lewis: (May 26, 2022) Strength and stability are essential for longevity Beth Lewis is a former professional dancer and a self-described “educator of movement” who has an unmatched ability to assimilate information and customize training plans from multiple training systems. In this episode, Beth takes us through how she identifies problematic movement patterns and postures to help individuals relieve pain, avoid injury, and move better within all types of exercise. She explains how movement is in fact a trainable skill and provides suggestions for what people can add to their exercise routine to benefit their health and longevity.  Note: In addition to the extensive show notes, for this episode Drive members also get a collection of 9 instructive exercise videos where Peter & Beth demonstrate several of the exercises and assessments discussed during the episode. If you’re a subscriber, you can now view these videos at the bottom of this page (make sure you are logged in). If you are not a member, you can learn more about the member benefits here. [56:30]; How Beth identifies an issue, addresses it, and keeps clients motivated [58:45]; Lifting weights, the Centenarian Decathlon, and dancing into old age [1:11:00]; The importance of the hamstrings versus abs [1:21:15]; Benefits of rowing, and why everyone should add it to their exercise regimen [1:27:15] Different roles of concentric versus eccentric strength [1:35:15]; Flexibility and high-intensity interval training (HIIT) [1:39:40]; Training versus playing sports, and the best type of activity for kids [1:43:00]; and More. § Show NotesBeth’s “way of no way” training philosophy [4:45] Resemblance of Beth’s approach to Bruce Lee’s approach to martial arts Bruce Lee’s approach was agnostic to form or discipline, extracting valuable components from a variety of disciplines Similarly, Beth is not partial to a single discipline Her approach draws from a variety of disciplines including: Functional Range Conditioning Postural Restoration Institute Dynamic Neuromuscular Stabilization   Beth’s background in dancing and how she ended up in New York City [7:30] Beth’s dancing career She participated in a variety of activities as a kid, including gymnastics, martial arts, soccer, and swimming After switching majors her junior year of college, she earned a degree in dance performance She danced professionally for four years with a dance company named Pilobolus This dance company is known for creating an athletic style of dance referred to as weight shifting  The dance technique was “actually quite similar to the way I teach to lift weights. It’s about sharing the load and working with the weight.” See this article for more about Pilobolus and the weight-sharing dance technique they developed Beth did not like the frequent travel associated with professional dancing, which is what led her to change professions Figure 1. Pilobolus dance theatre. Image credit: pilobolus.org   Beth’s transition to fitness coaching and how her training philosophy has evolved [12:45] Transition to training Beth was a fitness trainer prior to becoming a professional dancer Broadway didn’t appeal to her, so she decided to return to fitness training She split her time training clients between a few modes: Private 1 on 1 in general strength and conditioning Group classes  And then she got into rowing and started teaching classes at CITYROW Evolution in her philosophy on exercise training Beth’s initial philosophy was rooted in traditional strength and conditioning with particular emphasis on “do no harm” This was partly inspired by her time at EXOS She started to learn more about Olympic lifting and powerlifting at a new gym called Soho Strength Lab Beth became fascinated by why so many people were limited in the movements that they could do — “I would see all these accommodations and compensations happening and things that were just impossible and learning issues. Why can’t that person learn what I’m telling them to do?” She wanted to be more involved in helping people move better, more in line with physical therapy This led her to Functional Range Conditioning (FRC), which made a big difference in helping her help her clients move better   Functional Range Conditioning and scapular mobility [21:50] Functional Range Conditioning (FRC) is primarily focused on getting to end range of motion and reinforcing that range by challenging it The ability for the scapulae to glide across the rib cage vertically and horizontally is an important example of how FRC can be applied – this ability dictates capacity to move the shoulder and arm Controlled articular rotations (CARs) are a component of FRC that involve moving a joint through the biggest circle possible without any extraneous or compensatory movement Progressive and regressive angular isometric loading (PAILs and RAILs, respectively) is the application of isometric load to an end range of motion Despite the focus on movement and mobility, Beth considers FRC as more of a performance than a rehab modality Figure 2. Scapular articulations. Image credit: westcoastsci.com   An overview of Postural Restoration Institute, and Peter’s squat assessment [35:30] The Postural Restoration Institute (PRI) The PRI is more oriented towards clinicians and is focused on patterns throughout the body For example, the right side of the diaphragm is more compressed because the liver is on the right side, and this could be related to various restrictions throughout the body Example, most people when standing preferentially tend to load their right leg — “it’s probably more to do with we get more compression from the liver on that side.” The whole idea is because you’re on that right side a lot, especially in times of stress, that you’re going to get more repetitive injury on the right. And the left side just becomes kind of weak and almost useless. Peter’s enlightening squat assessment Peter and Beth first met in January 2019 At the time, Peter had some minor complaints mostly about his right SI joint and right elbow Peter assumed other than those minor issues, everything else was “fine” Then, Beth has Peter do a squat assessment and observed the following: Standing on his right side A dent right above his iliac crest from the compression on the right side A left scapular hike  And he was spinning out slightly to the left Figure 3. Peter’s pre- and post-squat photos.    The important connection between the ribs and breathing [39:45] “Making sure that your breath can be wide and three-dimensional and easy is vital for creating good, efficient, coordinated movement.” The ribs are your center of mass, and respiration is one of our constant stresses We breath 20,000+ times per day – inefficiencies in breathing can therefore have large effects The ribs have important relevance to breathing – if they do not externally rotate during exhalation, inhalation will be altered and it can lead to anterior tilt, rib flare, scapular retraction, or forward head posture Ultimately, this can lead to plantar fasciitis, pain in a variety of places, or even anxiety   The role of sitting and external stress in chronic muscular tension [42:30] Another constant stress is gravity — How are you working with or against gravity?  If you’re not breathing well, if you’re not dealing with gravity well, that has a high cost.  You’re having to hold this and you’re going to have that loading all of the time. What is at the root of this problem? 1-Sitting too much  Beth adds that sitting a lot is not good, but it’s more about the sitting in the same position In other words, taking breaks and changing sitting position is important “It’s never good to be in the same position all the time. But I think it’s more of your eyes are always fixed.” 2-Chronic stress (as opposed to acute distress)  More on stress External stress has a big impact on body tension Causes you to not sleep well Worried about finances, meeting deadlines at work Even staring at a screen—Your eyes are always fixed on the screen so you’re missing out a lot of the peripheral parts of vision, which is stressful because you don’t know what’s going on around you. We have more chronic stress than our ancestors (who mostly experienced acute stress)   Importance of maintaining use of your toes, minimalist footwear, and toe yoga [44:30] Footwear Peter says going from a minimalist foot pattern to a heavily supported shoe has altered our attachment to the ground Beth also considers modern footwear to be a problem, particularly because it decreases one’s ability to use their toes — “If we’re never experiencing load through the toes and the forefoot and you’re never feeling your feet you’re going to lose that.” ⇒ Subscribers get an exclusive discount to Xero brand minimalist shoes Toe Yoga Taken from FRC, Beth has her clients do “toe yoga” to help regain and maintain capacity to use the toes This basically involves spreading the toes apart and moving the big toe and other toes up and down independently of each other, all while keeping the rest of the foot relatively still Importance of maintaining use of your toes The ability to use your toes is important because they dampen force Modern shoes often squeeze your toes and minimize the use of your toes therefore your body becomes accustomed to not needing them  Imagine wearing restrictive gloves on your hands your whole life and what that would do to your fingers “People don’t think about their toes and their feet until there’s a problem. Above your waist is two-thirds of your mass. They’re basically supporting that mass all the time and pushing you through space.”   Dynamic Neuromuscular Stabilization (DNS) [48:30] Dynamic Neuromuscular Stabilization (DNS) is based on a re-engineering of the development of movement patterns that occurs between three months of age and walking The idea of that we are born with the innate ability to move efficiently, but by the time kids are school age (6) they are sitting all day and starting to lose the natural movement patterns It was originally developed to help kids with cerebral palsy, but is now used to help anyone with movement deficiencies Although Beth likes the concept of DNS, she is not as familiar with it as other disciplines and does not use it as much   A different view on knee valgus [52:45] Knee valgus is inward movement of the knee towards the midline and is generally considered an injury risk Beth believes context is important here: Completely avoiding knee valgus is not realistic or appropriate  “So train knee valgus, because it’s going to happen in life. You’re going to bend down to pick something off the floor and your knee is not going to be perfectly in line with your hip and your second toe. It’s going to happen.” However, when exercising with heavy weights (i.e., 65% of capacity or more), more care should be taken to execute the best movement possible, including avoidance of knee valgus Figure 4. Knee valgus and varus. Image credit: allhealthpost.com How much of movement do you think is or should be conscious versus should be subconscious?  “I think that movement in everyday life should be as subconscious as possible.” says Beth A lot of people that are in pain or discomfort or worried about hurting themselves have this really big bracing strategy in their trunk.  A person needs to instead be reactive and adaptive to be able to respond to different changes in their environment Being too fixated on making things conscious leads to being less adaptive How do you take them from subconsciously doing something incorrectly to subconsciously doing it correctly? Being very cautious about it If their muscles around their spine are quite loaded, for example, Beth would have them work in a way to unload them, to give them a little more space, because this has a high cost   Is there such a thing as “bad posture”? [56:30] “The only time it’s bad posture is when you don’t have another option.” —Beth Lewis  Beth does not believe in there being a such thing as bad posture She believes that moving around and never maintaining a single posture for too long is more important than superiority of any one particular posture Counteracting sitting Get up and move often Don’t sit in the same position the whole time Your pose perception just kind of turns off—“You forget that you’re supposed to move. . .if you don’t use it, it you lose it.”  But what about, for example… Don’t we know that too much looking down is going to create unbelievable cervical strain? Beth says, “I honestly don’t know if I can answer that because there has been studies where no, it’s just like saying if you’re deadlifting with a flexed spine all the time, there has been studies that it doesn’t create any problems. But you would have to do an assessment to see the full picture of the human to see.”   How Beth identifies an issue, addresses it, and keeps clients motivated [58:45] How can two people have the same movement pattern, yet only one gets injured?  What does Beth attribute to that? How they tolerate load And her intuition is that it’s mostly environmental (and less so genetic) When Beth is working with someone for the first time, how does she know if what she’s seeing is a problem versus an adaptation? “All I can do is address what I see.” For example, if someone is standing a particular way as their response to gravity, then she’d give them a different option — not because it’s “bad” but it could be causing them discomfort — and a different option could get them out of discomfort and make them more adaptable. Example: Beth assessment and treatment of Peter Peter came to Beth with SI joint pain Beth noticed he had less stretchability or mobility on the right side of your rib cage Beth did a lot of breathing work with Peter because he was also presenting with a pretty significant bilateral rib flare Beth calls the rib flaring Peter’s “strategy” for moving through life (basic walking, deadlift, etc.) Peter’s QLs (big muscles in the lower part of your back) were locked and loaded 24/7 which explains the rib flaring, anterior tilt of the pelvis This is not uncommon—Many people have restrictions that are preventing them from moving well, including locked quadratus lumborum muscles, rib flare, and anterior pelvic tilt It can require a lot of time and practice to reverse such restrictions, which can make it difficult to get buy in for the process The process is not as fun as bootcamp-style “crushing it” workouts, which also contributes to difficulty with buy in Plus, exercising like this with restrictions can either make it more difficult to reverse any present restrictions or even make them worse How does Beth keep clients motivated to keep going? First, she educates them the best she can, “I am very real.” Pointing out progress She constantly points out the little improvements, taking progress photos, etc. Reminding clients of wins, such as Peter’s alleviation of sacroiliac joint pain, helps “The people that are successful pay attention when they practice. It’s hard to pay attention . . .But having that control over your body, you have to pay attention to control it.”    Lifting weights, the Centenarian Decathlon, and dancing into old age [1:11:00] Beth’s appreciation for lifting weights  She’s a “meathead at heart” She particularly loves to deadlift (trap bar and straight bar) She doesn’t have all of her clients deadlift, but she does emphasize split leg exercises because of their applicability to hip stability and their greater potential for exposing movement limitations Examples: Split squats, walking lunges, single leg Romanian deadlift, etc. Beth’s version of the “Centenarian Decathlon” includes the ability to: Walk to the grocery store and carry the groceries home Be able walk up stairs Do at least one pull up and push up Continue dancing ⇒ Hear about Peter’s Centenarian Decathlon from an AMA #5  Dancing (and moving well) into old age Dancing requires a level of coordination and balance that goes beyond most other activities It is possible to improve balance through training Moving with the eyes closed is one of the things Beth has clients do to improve their balance Balance declines with age and it’s better to address deficiencies sooner rather than later – otherwise, for someone in their 40s or 50s, balance will only get worse Beth has an 80-year old client who came to here unable to get up and down off of the floor without assistance – now he can do so on his own, and only using one hand for support From Peter’s perspective, an important incentive for maintaining good movement capacity into old age is being able to get on the floor to play with grandkids   The importance of the hamstrings versus abs [1:21:15] Beth’s perspective on abs: “If you’re a bodybuilder, they’re a thing. But it’s not a big deal.” She believes that too much bracing with the abdominal muscles limits reflexiveness and adaptability and, in turn, resilience Beth emphasizes the importance of the hamstrings more so than the abdominals for assisting posterior pelvic tilt She has her clients do bicep curls in a kneeling position to help facilitate activation of the hamstrings Another reason why using the abdominals for posterior pelvic tilt is less desirable is because it limits exhalation When Peter first started working with Beth, he relied more on his quadriceps to deadlift because of his difficulty activating his hamstrings “You would kind of slip your knees forward and scoot under it.” “It’s a good strategy if you’re trying to use your quads and you don’t care that much about your back.   Benefits of rowing, and why everyone should add it to their exercise regimen [1:27:15] “I think every human should row.” —Beth Lewis She initially started to teach rowing based on the convenience of CITYROW being close to another gym she taught at As she learned more about rowing, she began to think of it as a great way to promote backward movement – something most people do not do  much and lose the sense of Rowing also promotes scapular mobility Beth has used rowing to help resolve back pain in a lot of her clients Beth equates the starting position of rowing to the start of a deadlift, where the posterior chain muscles are pre-loaded The entire drive portion of rowing is actually similar to the concentric phase of a deadlift One of the hardest parts of rowing well is learning to lessen tension while pulling in the bar and relaxing during the return to the starting position Rowing is 60% legs, 30% hips, and only 10% gripping and pulling the bar Peter’s back when rowing Hardest part for Peter is keeping the abs relaxed and ribs down This is due to his “strategy of overbracing his QLs His QLs would be in pain during and post workout His QL pain vanished when he started strapless rowing and learning to relax his hands once the bar crossed his knees Beth explains: “when you actually can relax the grip, this stuff can relax easier, because your arms and rib cage have a direct correlation. So if you’re hanging on for dear life, this stuff is just so tight” How Beth uses rowing for clients Step 1 would be learning technique with strokes being less than 24 She will then add weight and sometimes substitute rowing for deadlifts (like 10 rows per set) She doesn’t start doing higher speeds for a while because coordination goes out the window She also sometimes does single leg rowing Beth also does zone 2 exercise on a rowing machine She also loves it for runners — Less load, less impact on the lower leg, and also really works the hips   Different roles of concentric versus eccentric strength [1:35:25] An example of eccentric versus concentric strength that is extremely relevant to sports is accelerating and decelerating, respectively Beth equates lack of eccentric strength to a sports car without brakes Eccentric strength also promotes control, such as in the descent phase of a squat or lunge Figure 5. Isometric, concentric, and eccentric muscle contractions. Image credit: vickphysiotherapy.com   Flexibility and high-intensity interval training (HIIT) [1:39:40] Beth considers flexibility to be relative to the range of motion that can be controlled – she considers control and load tolerance to be more important She uses people who can do splits but are unable to control the movement as an example of flexibility exceeding control capacity Although Beth does not put a lot of emphasis on hamstring flexibility, she does think that people should be able to touch their toes Beth thinks that HIIT should be done about 20% of the time, although she also acknowledges that most people need more Zone 2 exercise In regard to clients who want to “crush it all the time,” Beth tells them “you should rarely feel like death. It’s just not what it’s about.”   Training versus playing sports, and the best type of activity for kids [1:43:00] Sports versus exercise training: Beth believes that sports should not be used as a replacement for exercise “You have to be so reactive and it’s so stressful when you’re playing a sport that you’re not learning anything. And for me, training is about learning. Paying attention and learning, and that learning will actually help you in your sport.” Activity during childhood Beth believes that kids should spend more time playing and less time at desks and on screens Kids who spend time playing and are involved with sports will have a better foundation of movement and will learn movement changes more easily However, sport specialization and repetitive sports can hurt rather than help movement capacity § EXERCISE VIDEOS PAILs and RAILs Should be done at the end of a workout because they are neurologically challenging Prior to starting a pail or rail, a stretch should be held for about two minutes This is about how long it takes for neurological signaling to stabilize PAILs are performed by isometrically contracting the stretched muscles, while still stretched The intensity of the contraction is progressively increased while maintaining appropriate posture/positioning RAILs are performed by isometrically contracting the muscles opposing the stretched muscles, as if creating additional stretch The stretch is continually maintained while switching from the PAIL to the RAIL – there is no rest period One to two rounds for a particular stretch is adequate.   Hamstring Control The purpose of the exercise is to learn how to activate the hamstrings with minimal activation of the abdominals If done properly, breathing should feel normal and not restrained The exercise is initiated with posterior pelvic tilt  Similar to PAILs and RAILs, the intensity of isometric contraction should be progressively increased Finally, the hips should be lifted about an inch off the floor to further increase the load   Deadlift Prior to initiating the lift, a “wedge” is developed, which is basically a pre-loading of the appropriate muscles A strong grip is established The arms are externally (outwardly) rotated  The hips are shifted back and tension is established in the legs It is important that the hips move back to maintain emphasis on the appropriate muscles Peter used to unknowingly shift his weight forward, which puts more emphasis on the quadriceps Peter primarily deadlifts with a hex bar, but periodically uses a straight bar (with lighter load) to reinforce emphasis on the hamstrings The isometric dumbbell deadlift can be used to train the “wedge,” or to maintain strength when access to equipment is limited (i.e., during travel)   Eccentric-Focused Step-Up Mimics the gait pattern This exercise is just as much about positioning and posture (particularly the ribs) as it is about leg strengthening   Breathing Assessment Should feel ribs expanding and retracting Reaching the arms up and protracting the scapulae helps promote proper rib positioning   Assessments Toe touch More about how the spine segments than hamstring flexibility Shifting weight back to the heels and a relatively flat lumbar spine indicate limited hamstring control Late stance phase Tests the reflexivity of the lower leg Doubles as both an assessment and training 80-85% of weight is on front leg Eyes are closed  Head is rotated right and left for vestibular challenge Hugging a ball is helpful when back muscles are used excessively This helps to establish more of a posterior pelvic tilt, which helps to relax the back muscles   Segmental Cat Cow and CARs Segmental Cat Cow Doubles as both an assessment and training for spinal segmentation Segmental movement implies movement being spread across multiple vertebrae rather than movement being isolated to one area When movement isolated to one area, it creates a lot of unwanted shear stress in the spine To allow for proper rib movement, elbows should not be locked Starting from the hips, back extension (arching) is performed by sequentially focusing on one vertebra at a time Back flexion (rounding) is then sequentially performed (again starting at the hips) one vertebra at a time Scapular CARs Similar to segmental cat cow, this doubles as an assessment and training Movement should be isolated to the shoulder blades – arms should not move far from sides Head and spine should remain relatively still Can also be done with arms forward instead of at sides to accentuate protraction and retraction Related to this variation, Peter explains why scapular protraction is important for archery Can also be done on hands and knees to apply load, but proficiency without load should be developed prior to attempting this variation   Tricep Extensions and Eccentric Split Squat Tricep Extensions Example of FRC and applying challenge at end range of motion Not a lot of weight is needed – Peter uses only 5-7 lbs Positioning the shoulder in greater extension (elbow further behind torso) is what enables challenging of end range Eccentric Split Squat Spinal muscles should be unloaded to ensure that control is primarily coming from legs Descent should be paced at a count of 5, Ascent at a count of 1 Knee should only lightly touch the floor Main emphasis is on the control of the descent and bottom position Restrained breathing and elevation of the shoulders during the ascent are indications of a lack of control   Rowing Positioning and Mechanics Heels can be moderately elevated at the catch position, but with good sense of toes and forefoot The catch position is similar to the deadlift wedge Hips should open while pushing back from the catch position A common mistake is to extend the back rather than opening the hips A related but opposite mistake is pushing the hips back ahead of the body Pull of the bar at the end of the motion should feel easy Another common mistake is pulling the bar too soon Keeping the arms too tense is common among people with back pain During recovery, should feel a sense of being pulled in by the bar Practicing without the toe straps helps to reinforce proper mechanics This should be done gently to avoid hitting and/or falling off of the back end of the rower Rowing can also be done single leg, which is particularly valuable for people with a leg injury Supporting drills Isometrically loading the catch position can be helpful for learning to develop the appropriate amount of tension This was helpful for Peter, who initially felt that he was not generating enough tension at this position This is quite similar to the isometric dumbbell deadlift Isolating and focusing on the leg movement portion helps to reinforce proper synchronization of knee and hip movement (they should open at the same time) Doing “half slides” (minus the full catch) helps to reinforce proper timing of tensing and relaxing the core Pace and Protocol Should start at lower speeds (strokes per minute) Since there is considerable cognitive skill involved with rowing technique, slower speeds facilitate reinforcement of proper technique Pace can gradually be increased as technique becomes grooved Beth recommends doing 1-1.5 minutes at a time with 30-45 second breaks to allow for a cognitive reset This can be repeated many times to make it into a cardiovascular workout Speed can be slowly increased as these cycles are repeated §Selected Links / Related MaterialThe dance company that Beth danced LewisBeth is a former professional dancer and a self-described “educator of movement” who has an unmatched ability to assimilate information and customize training plans from multiple training systems. She grew up in a small town in South Georgia where she was a competitive gymnast, swimmer, dancer, soccer player and martial artist. Beth received her undergraduate degree in Dance Performance from The University of Georgia and then joined with Pilobolus where she spent 4 years touring the world dancing. After retiring from dance, Beth moved to NYC to really dive into health and wellness, and has worked with a variety of gyms, including being the Programming Director of CityRow.  Her continuing education in Functional Range Conditioning, Postural Restoration, Dynamic Neuromuscular Stabilization, and applied neurology has turned her into a strength coach with non-traditional methods.
